item.title: How Microsoft Decides When Xbox Games Come To PlayStation
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-microsoft-decides-when-xbox-games-come-to-playstation/1100-6528310/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The newest big Xbox exclusive game, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, is officially available for everyone today, December 9--that is, if you own an Xbox or a PC or subscribe to Game Pass Ultimate. The adventure game doesn't come to PlayStation 5 until Spring 2025. In a new interview, Xbox president of game content and studios Matt Booty elaborated on Microsoft's decision-making process when it comes to bringing Xbox games to rival platforms.

"We are very much making the [exclusivity and windowing] decisions on a game-by-game basis," Booty told Variety, echoing comments he and other Xbox executives have made before.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle - Official Launch Trailer

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Booty went on to say that each of Microsoft's numerous studios are in "a little bit of a different position," but he didn't elaborate about what this means as it relates to exclusivity. Beyond that, the decision on "spacing" when a game might come to a rival platform after Xbox needs to also factor in production timelines, Booty said.

"We want to make sure there's a great experience for our Xbox players, and then the gap between [when it becomes available on PlayStation] is as much a production decision as it is anything else. This is a game that was in production before we acquired Bethesda, even," Booty said.

Microsoft announced it would acquire ZeniMax, the parent company of Machine Games studio owner Bethesda, in 2020--the deal officially closed in 2021.

After Microsoft acquired ZeniMax, it acknowledged that making some of Bethesda's games exclusive to Xbox, including Starfield and The Great Circle, would lead to millions of lost game sales. Microsoft said at the time that it would aim to make that up with Game Pass sign-ups and hardware sales.

In February 2024, Microsoft disclosed that Game Pass had reached 34 million members, but the company hasn't revealed a new figure since. We do know that the launch of Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 led to a boost in subscribers, though. As for Xbox hardware sales, US video game industry research company Circana reported that Xbox Series X|S sales dropped 18% in October 2024 compared to October 2023 (PS5 and Switch sales in the US were down, too).

The Great Circle is coming to PS5 in Spring 2025, but Microsoft has yet to reveal a specific release date or any other details pertaining to the PlayStation edition of the game. For more, be sure to read GameSpot's Indiana Jones and the Great Circle review and consult our guides hub to hit the ground running.

Some of Microsoft's other games that have landed on PlayStation (and Switch in some cases) in the past year have included Sea of Thieves, Grounded, Pentiment, and Hi-Fi Rush. Microsoft's Minecraft series, meanwhile, has been on PlayStation and Switch for years.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: A New Squid Game-Inspired Xbox Controller Is Available For Preorder
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/a-new-squid-game-inspired-xbox-controller-is-available-for-preorder/1100-6528301/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Scuf has announced a new Squid Game-themed version of its Instinct Pro wireless controller for Xbox and PC. The gamepad will launch for $240 on December 20, and fans can preorder it now at Best Buy.

Aside from the unique visual design, the rest of the controller matches the features of the standard Scuf Instinct Pro, including four rear remappable paddles and the ability to save and swap up to three mappings with the press of a button. The controller also offers interchangeable thumbstick styles--including a taller stick with a domed top--and Scuf's Instant Triggers (trigger locks). It supports Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, and Windows PC via wireless and wired connections.

At $240, the Squid Game Pink Guard Edition is just $10 more than the standard Instinct Pro, so if you're in the admittedly niche overlap of Squid Game fans looking for a pro-style controller for Xbox or PC--or you really like the color pink--this is a good option. That said, if the feature set caught your eye but you would prefer a different color option, you can grab the Scuf Instinct Pro for just $190 (was $230) at Amazon and Best Buy. The color options differ between retailers--Amazon has the Gray, Black, Blue, and Red models available, while Best Buy is discounting the Steel Gray, White, and Red Fracture versions.

More Scuf Controllers

  • Scuf Insinct Pro Wireless Controller - Gray, Black, Red, or Blue (Xbox, PC) -- $190 ($230)
  • Scuf Insinct Pro Wireless Controller - Gray, White, Fracture (Xbox, PC) -- $190 ($230)
  • Scut Envision Pro Wireless Controller (PC) -- $150 ($180)

For an even more affordable option, the Scuf Envision Pro wireless PC controller is down to $150 (was $180). This model is PC-only and has a slightly different design, but features many of the same functions, including swappable thumbsticks, adjustable trigger sensitivity, four remappable buttons, and button mapping profiles, plus an additional set of side-mounted buttons and five extra programmable buttons on the front face of the controller. It's available in Steel Grey, White/Gray, and White/Black color schemes.

The Scuf Instinct Pro is one of many pro-style controllers competing with Microsoft's Elite Series 2 Pro, our pick for the best premium Xbox controller.

But it's worth noting that the Elite Series 2 is on sale for its best price of the year at multiple retailers. You can get the Elite Series 2 for only $124 at Walmart or Amazon, or $125 at Target. Just be aware that Amazon estimates orders won't be delivered until January.
